content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Luis Hernandez: Sure, let's start from the beginning. I was born in a small town in Mexico, but my family moved to the United States when I was just a baby. We settled in Pacific, Oregon, a coastal city not too far from Eugene. My parents worked hard, but they didn't go beyond finishing elementary school, which made it challenging for them to find stable jobs. They were both working multiple part-time jobs to make ends meet, so we lived in a modest home and struggled to keep up with the costs. Despite the financial struggles, my parents instilled in me the importance of education and hard work. They often talked about the sacrifices they made to give us a better life. I remember going to school and feeling grateful for the opportunity to learn, even though our family income was far below average.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Luis Hernandez: There was a moment in high school that really shaped who I am today. I was struggling to balance schoolwork with helping out around the house and taking care of my younger siblings. One day, my guidance counselor approached me and suggested I apply for a scholarship program that could help with college expenses. At first, I wasn't sure if I qualified or if it was worth applying, given our financial situation. But my counselor encouraged me to apply, saying that every little bit helps and that it could open doors for me. So, I decided to take the leap and applied. Much to my surprise, I was accepted into the program and received a full scholarship to a local community college. That experience taught me the importance of seizing opportunities, no matter how small they may seem. It also showed me that there are resources available if you're willing to seek them out. From that point on, I became more proactive about my education and set my sights on eventually transferring to a four-year university.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Luis Hernandez: That scholarship was a turning point for me. It wasn't just about the financial aid; it gave me a sense of purpose and direction. I realized that despite the challenges we faced, there were still ways to achieve something greater. It was a reminder that no matter how difficult things might seem, there's always a way forward if you're willing to put in the effort. Since then, I've tried to stay focused on my goals and to pay it forward whenever I can.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Luis Hernandez: Absolutely. If someone had lent a helping hand during those times, it would have made a huge difference. My parents did what they could, but sometimes it's hard to see beyond your own immediate needs. Having someone believe in me and offer support, even in small ways, could have been a game-changer. It made me realize that there are people and organizations out there who want to help, and that knowledge has stayed with me ever since.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Luis Hernandez: Currently, I'm married to my wife, Maria. We've been together for about five years now and got married last year. She works as a nurse, and we have a wonderful little boy named Luis Jr., who is two years old. Having him has been the most rewarding experience of my life. It's amazing to see him grow and learn new things every day. Our relationship is built on mutual respect and understanding, and we both value our independence while supporting each other through thick and thin.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics, it's clear that the core of my journey revolves around the challenges and opportunities that have shaped who I am today. Growing up in a modest household, the importance of education and hard work was deeply instilled in me by my parents. The turning point came when I received a scholarship to community college, which not only provided financial relief but also gave me a sense of direction and purpose. This experience highlighted the importance of seeking out support and resources, and it has influenced my approach to life and my desire to help others. Additionally, the addition of my family, particularly my wife Maria and our son Luis Jr., has brought immense joy and responsibility. Their love and support have been instrumental in my personal growth and have reinforced my commitment to providing a better future for our family.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Luis Hernandez: My parents are still a part of my life, although they live in a different city now. They moved to a smaller town near Eugene for my dad's health reasons. We still keep in touch regularly, and they often visit us. Our relationship with them is very close, and we appreciate the sacrifices they made for us. They're proud of everything we've accomplished, and their support means the world to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Luis Hernandez: I do have a few close friends from my neighborhood who I've known since childhood. We grew up playing together and still keep in touch. They're like an extended family to me, and we support each other through both good and bad times. One of my best friends, Carlos, is a single father and we often talk about parenting and life in general. He's a great guy, and I admire his strength and resilience.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Luis Hernandez: Our neighborhood is a mix of older homes and newer constructions, with a nice blend of families and young professionals. It's close to the city center, so it's convenient for shopping and other errands. There's a small park nearby where Luis Jr. and I like to play, and the local library is always a good place for me to catch up on reading. The community is pretty tight-knit, and everyone looks out for one another, which is comforting. I feel lucky to live here, especially knowing that we're in a safe and supportive environment.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Luis Hernandez: I definitely feel safe in our neighborhood. The police presence is reassuring, and the community watch program is active, which gives everyone a sense of security. Of course, like anywhere, there can always be concerns, but overall, it feels like a place where we can raise our family without too many worries.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Luis Hernandez: Living here has its challenges, of course. Raising a child, keeping a roof over our heads, and managing finances can be tough. But having a supportive community makes it easier. We participate in local events and activities, which keeps us connected and provides us with a sense of belonging. It's a small victory, but it matters a lot.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, it's clear that my life has been profoundly shaped by the people and community around me. Starting with my family, my wife Maria and our son Luis Jr. bring immense joy and responsibility, and their love and support have been instrumental in my personal growth. My parents, though living in a different city, remain a constant source of pride and encouragement. The neighborhood where we live is a mix of older homes and newer constructions, offering a blend of families and young professionals. It's close to the city center, making it convenient for daily errands and social connections. The local park and library are places where Luis Jr. and I spend quality time, and the community watch program provides a sense of security. The tight-knit community and active police presence contribute to a safe and supportive environment. Overall, the combination of family, friends, and community has made living here a rewarding experience, despite the challenges of raising a child and managing finances.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Luis Hernandez: A typical week for us involves a lot of routine but also some flexibility. During the weekdays, I usually get up early to make breakfast and help Luis Jr. with his morning routine. After he goes to daycare, I stay home to manage the house and any other tasks that need attention. In the evenings, I try to cook dinner and spend some quality time with Maria before she goes to work. Weekends are a bit more relaxed, with more time for errands, visits to the park, or just hanging out at home. It's a lot, but seeing Luis Jr. grow and knowing we're doing our best to provide a good life for him makes it all worthwhile.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Luis Hernandez: I'm keeping house right now, which means managing the household, cooking meals, and taking care of Luis Jr. until Maria gets home from work. It's a lot of responsibility, but I enjoy being able to be there for him and support Maria. Even though I don't have a traditional job outside the home, I find it fulfilling to ensure everything runs smoothly and that we're taking care of our family's needs.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Luis Hernandez: Another routine I have is attending church on Sundays. It's important to me to maintain my Catholic faith and to be a part of the community there. The priest is a mentor to me, and I often find comfort and guidance in the teachings. On other days, I might join a local sports league or attend community meetings to stay involved in the neighborhood. It helps me feel connected and gives me a sense of purpose beyond just taking care of the house and family.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Luis Hernandez: Recently, we've started homeschooling Luis Jr. due to the pandemic. It's been a bit of a challenge, but it's also allowed us to bond more and make learning fun for him. I've been trying to find educational resources online and adapting them to fit his interests. It's a new routine for all of us, but I'm enjoying being his first teacher and seeing how much he's learning.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Luis Hernandez: During the school year, Luis Jr.'s routine starts early. He wakes up around 7:00 AM, and we do a quick morning routine before he heads off to daycare. When he comes back around 3:00 PM, we usually have a snack and a brief playtime. Then, we focus on his homework and any educational activities. After that, we might do some art projects or read stories together. We try to keep the evenings light and relaxing so he can unwind. As for after-school activities, he loves playing soccer with his friends at the park, and we've signed him up for a few classes at the community center, like music and art. It's a busy but joyful schedule.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, it's clear that my life has been profoundly shaped by the people and community around me. Starting with my family, my wife Maria and our son Luis Jr. bring immense joy and responsibility, and their love and support have been instrumental in my personal growth. My parents, though living in a different city, remain a constant source of pride and encouragement. The neighborhood where we live is a mix of older homes and newer constructions, offering a blend of families and young professionals. It's close to the city center, making it convenient for daily errands and social connections. The local park and library are places where Luis Jr. and I spend quality time, and the community watch program provides a sense of security. The tight-knit community and active police presence contribute to a safe and supportive environment. Overall, the combination of family, friends, and community has made living here a rewarding experience, despite the challenges of raising a child and managing finances. Managing the household and homeschooling Luis Jr. during the pandemic has been a new routine, but it's also allowed us to bond more and make learning fun for him. Attending church on Sundays is important to me, and joining local sports leagues or community meetings helps me feel connected and gives me a sense of purpose beyond just taking care of the house and family.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Luis Hernandez: My health is generally good, thank you for asking. I try to stay active by walking and doing some light exercises like yoga, which helps keep me in shape. Luis Jr. and I often go for walks in the park, and I find it's a great way to bond and stay healthy. I also try to eat well and maintain a balanced diet, which is easier with the time we spend at home preparing meals together. Sometimes, I worry about my dad's health, but he's doing better now thanks to the medical care he's receiving. I make sure to check in with him regularly and support him in any way I can.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Luis Hernandez: Staying healthy can be a challenge, especially with the demands of raising a child and managing household responsibilities. It's hard to find time for regular exercise, but I try to prioritize it. Luis Jr. and I have a routine where we walk to the park, and that's a great way to get some fresh air and move our bodies. Also, cooking at home allows us to control what we eat, which is important for both of us. I find that when I'm taking care of myself, I have more energy to be there for Luis Jr. and Maria.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Luis Hernandez: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some back pain due to the strain from carrying Luis Jr. and doing all the physical work around the house. It's not a big deal, but it does remind me to be more mindful of my body and to take breaks when needed. Luckily, I've been able to manage it with some stretching and heat therapy. I also joined a support group at the local gym a few months ago, and it's been helpful to connect with others who understand what I'm going through.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Luis Hernandez: The back pain has been a constant reminder to me about the importance of balance and self-care. It's something I'm still working on, but I try to prioritize it. I've also noticed that staying active and maintaining a healthy lifestyle helps me manage the stress of daily life, especially when it comes to caring for Luis Jr. and supporting Maria.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Luis Hernandez: Over the past year, life has been a mix of challenges and rewards. Raising Luis Jr. has been incredibly fulfilling, but it's also demanding. The pandemic added an extra layer of uncertainty and stress, especially with homeschooling. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed, but I tried to stay positive and remember why we're doing this. Seeing Luis Jr.'s progress and watching him develop his own interests and personality has been heartwarming. We've also had some tough times, like when he got sick or when we ran into financial difficulties. Those moments tested our resilience, but they also strengthened our bond. Overall, it's been a journey of learning and growing, both as a parent and as a person.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, it's clear that my life has been profoundly shaped by the challenges and joys of raising Luis Jr. and managing the responsibilities of family life. The transition to homeschooling during the pandemic has been both a challenge and an opportunity to bond with Luis Jr. and tailor his learning experience to his interests. Maintaining a healthy routine, despite the demands of childcare and household management, has been crucial for my well-being. Regular walks in the park and engaging in light exercises like yoga have become essential parts of my routine, helping me stay active and mentally grounded. Cooking at home allows us to control our diet, which is important for both Luis Jr. and me. The support group I joined has also been beneficial, connecting me with others facing similar challenges and reinforcing the importance of self-care. Overall, the combination of family, health, and community has made navigating these recent changes a more manageable and rewarding experience.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Luis Hernandez: Depression and anxiety have been something I've dealt with at times, especially during the pandemic. There were moments when the stress of balancing work at home, taking care of Luis Jr., and managing our finances felt overwhelming. But I've tried to lean on my faith, the support group I joined, and the love from my family and friends to help me through those tough times. It's not always easy, but I believe in the power of community and the importance of taking care of my mental health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Luis Hernandez: It's been a mix of emotions for us. Raising Luis Jr. and managing the household during such a challenging time has certainly taken its toll on us all. Maria and I support each other, and our relationship has grown stronger because of it. Luis Jr. is our little sunshine, and seeing him thrive despite the obstacles makes everything worth it. We've leaned on our community and each other to get through tough times. It's not always easy, but we're grateful for the support and the love we share.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Luis Hernandez: Religion and spirituality are very important to me. Growing up, my parents instilled in me the values of faith and community, and I've carried those teachings with me. Attending church on Sundays is a non-negotiable part of my routine, and it provides me with a sense of peace and connection to something bigger than myself. The support and guidance I receive from the community there are invaluable, especially during tough times. I find that praying and reflecting on my faith helps me navigate the challenges of everyday life and gives me strength to face whatever comes our way.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Luis Hernandez: I don't use Facebook or Instagram as much as I probably should. I do have a few friends who post updates, and occasionally I'll scroll through to see what they're up to. But honestly, I find it easier to stay connected through phone calls and text messages. I think social media can be a double-edged sword—sometimes it's nice to see what's happening in the wider world, but it can also make me feel a bit isolated if I compare my life to what others seem to have. Still, I try to keep an eye on the local news and community events to stay informed about what's going on around us.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Luis Hernandez: Sometimes, I do use Facebook to connect with friends or family members who live far away. It's nice to see photos and updates, but I try to avoid comparing my life to theirs. Instead, I focus on the positive aspects of my life and the support I receive from my community here. When we face tough times, like financial stress or health issues, I lean on the support group I mentioned earlier. They've been a lifeline, and I know I can reach out to them if I need advice or just someone to talk to.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, it's clear that the challenges and joys of raising Luis Jr. and managing the responsibilities of family life have been at the forefront of my experiences over the past year. The back pain I've been dealing with, especially during the pandemic, has been a constant reminder of the physical demands of caring for a young child. However, it has also pushed me to prioritize self-care and find ways to manage stress through exercise and community support. The transition to homeschooling has been both challenging and rewarding, allowing us to bond more and tailor Luis Jr.'s learning experience to his interests. While depression and anxiety have sometimes crept in, leaning on my faith, the support group I joined, and the love from my family and friends has helped me navigate these tough times. Overall, the combination of family, health, and community has made these recent changes a more manageable and rewarding experience, reinforcing the importance of finding balance and support in all aspects of life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Luis Hernandez: Over the past few months, my stress levels have fluctuated quite a bit. The pandemic has introduced a lot of uncertainty, and balancing homeschooling Luis Jr. with our household responsibilities can be overwhelming. I've found that taking breaks, doing some yoga, and talking things over with my friends in the support group have been helpful. It's also important to me to maintain a routine, even if it's a flexible one, because it gives me a sense of normalcy. I try to focus on the little victories, like seeing Luis Jr. learn something new or finding ways to make our home more comfortable despite limited resources. It's a constant process of finding balance and taking care of myself so I can be there for my family.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Luis Hernandez: Our biggest expenses last month were the mortgage, utilities, and groceries. The mortgage is a bit tight, but we're managing with Maria's income and my contributions. Utilities can be unpredictable, especially with the weather changing, but we try to be mindful of our usage. Groceries are a big part of our budget, and we try to stick to a list to avoid overspending. Fortunately, we've been able to save a little each month, which helps with unexpected expenses.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Luis Hernandez: It's usually around $2,500, but last month we spent a bit more on groceries because Luis Jr. started eating more solids and we needed to stock up on baby food. The mortgage is around $900, utilities are about $200, and groceries are typically around $800. We try to save a little each month, but it's not always easy. I also put aside some money for Luis Jr.'s activities and supplies, which adds up. It's a tight budget, but we're managing.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Luis Hernandez: We own our home, and it's a big responsibility, but it also gives us a sense of stability. Our mortgage is a fixed amount, which helps with budgeting, and we're aiming to save enough to eventually pay it off. Owning our home is something we both agree is important for our family's future.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Luis Hernandez: Over the past year, our bills have seen some fluctuations. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, and we had to budget accordingly. Spring brought some unexpected repairs, which added to our expenses. Summer was relatively stable, but with Luis Jr. starting daycare, we had to factor in those additional costs. Fall saw a dip in utility bills because of cooler temperatures, which was a welcome relief. Overall, it's been a bit of a rollercoaster, but we've managed to stay on top of things.

The recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 highlighted the challenges and support systems in my life, particularly focusing on my family, community, and mental health. Reflecting on these discussions, I realize how much my family and the support network around us have been a source of strength during tough times. The bond we share and the love from my wife Maria, our son Luis Jr., and our extended family has been instrumental in navigating the uncertainties of the past year. The support group I joined has also been a lifeline, providing emotional support and practical advice. While social media can sometimes feel isolating, it's reassuring to know that I can turn to friends and family for connection and assistance. The importance of prioritizing mental health and finding healthy coping mechanisms, like yoga and talking things over with friends, cannot be overstated. These reflections underscore the value of community and the need to lean on those around us during challenging times.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Luis Hernandez: We do have a savings account, but it's not a lot. We try to put aside a little each month, but it's a challenge, especially with the fluctuating expenses. I recently opened a separate account specifically for Luis Jr.'s education and activities, which we're trying to build up. It's not much, but it's a start.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Luis Hernandez: Last year, we've been trying to save for Luis Jr.'s education and future needs, but it's been tough. With the pandemic and the extra costs of homeschooling, we've had to be extra careful with our budget. We're trying to build up that savings account, but it feels like a constant juggling act. Still, every little bit helps, and we're hopeful that we can secure a brighter future for him.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Luis Hernandez: I've been keeping house, but I've also been working on building a small business idea on the side. It's something that came to me when I was looking for ways to supplement our income and maybe even turn into a full-time venture someday. I've been designing and selling custom crafts online, and it's been a rewarding way to express my creativity and contribute to our family's financial stability.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Luis Hernandez: Keeping house has been a full-time job, but I've been trying to find ways to incorporate my creative side. Designing and selling custom crafts online has been a great outlet for me. It's not a traditional 9-to-5 job, but it does give me a sense of accomplishment and allows me to contribute to our family's financial stability in a different way. It's a bit of a challenge balancing it all, but I find it rewarding.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Luis Hernandez: It's been a bit of a juggle, but the small business idea has been a silver lining. Designing and selling custom crafts online has given me something to look forward to and a sense of purpose outside of just taking care of the house and family. I spend a few hours each week on it, mainly during the evenings and weekends. It's not a lot, but it's a way to express myself creatively and maybe one day turn it into something bigger.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, it's clear that managing stress and finding coping strategies have been at the forefront of my experiences. The past year has brought a lot of challenges, especially with balancing homeschooling Luis Jr. and managing household responsibilities. I've found that taking breaks, doing yoga, and talking things over with friends in the support group have been helpful. It's important to me to maintain a routine, even if it's flexible, as it provides a sense of normalcy. Despite the tight budget and fluctuating expenses, we've been able to save a little each month, which helps with unexpected expenses. Owning our home is a significant responsibility, but it also gives us a sense of stability. The love and support from my family, particularly Maria, Luis Jr., and our extended family, have been instrumental in navigating these uncertainties. The support group I joined has been a lifeline, providing emotional support and practical advice. Prioritizing mental health and finding healthy coping mechanisms is crucial, and I'm grateful for the community around me that helps us through tough times.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Luis Hernandez: In total, how much did our household make in the past month? I think we brought in around $2,500, with Maria's nursing salary and my contributions from the small business. It's not a lot, but we're managing to cover our expenses and save a little bit.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Luis Hernandez: When it comes to my workplace, it's more of a home-based operation. I haven't been at my current 'job' for very long, just a few months now. My main responsibilities are managing the household and homeschooling Luis Jr., but I've been trying to incorporate some side work too. I'm not sure if I would call it a job in the traditional sense, but it keeps me engaged and allows me to contribute financially. There aren't any formal benefits like health insurance or paid time off, but the sense of fulfillment and the chance to be there for my family is priceless.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Luis Hernandez: The relationships at work... well, they're a bit different since it's more of a home-based operation. I don't have a manager or boss in the traditional sense, but I suppose you could say I'm my own boss! It's a lot of responsibility, but it also means I get to set my own schedule and manage my time as I see fit. My relationship with 'coworkers' is a bit unconventional too. I interact with the people in our community, like the neighbors and the folks at the local library and park, who are like a virtual team. We all pitch in and support each other, which is really nice.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Luis Hernandez: I find that having a flexible schedule helps a lot with managing everything. I can adjust my 'work' hours to fit in Luis Jr.'s nap times or when Maria is working late. It's not always easy to predict, but it allows me to be there for him and still handle household tasks. I've learned to prioritize and make the most of the time I have.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Luis Hernandez: Overall, I feel like we're getting by, but there's always room for improvement. It's not glamorous, but having a roof over our heads and food on the table is what truly matters. I'm grateful for the support from my community and the little successes we have along the way.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40, it's clear that managing the household and supporting our family financially has been a significant challenge over the past year. The bills have fluctuated with the changing seasons and unexpected expenses, making it a constant juggling act. Despite the tight budget, we've managed to keep up with our mortgage, utilities, and groceries, while also trying to save a little each month for Luis Jr.'s future needs. The small business idea of designing and selling custom crafts online has been a way to supplement our income and provide a sense of purpose. It's not a traditional job with benefits, but the flexibility and the chance to be there for our family is invaluable. The support from our community, including the local church and the support group, has been a lifeline, providing both emotional support and practical advice. It's a bumpy road, but we're managing, and every little bit helps in securing a better future for Luis Jr.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Luis Hernandez: My parents did work for pay while I was growing up, but it was never steady. They had different jobs at different times, mostly in retail or food service. It was always a bit uncertain, but they managed to keep food on the table and a roof over our heads.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Luis Hernandez: My parents' work was often unpredictable. My dad would work in construction during the summer months when the weather was good, but in the winter, he'd find temporary jobs at local businesses. My mom worked in a grocery store, usually during the evenings or weekends. Their most important activities were making sure they could provide for us and keep us fed and clothed, even if it meant taking on multiple jobs. It was tough, but they never complained and always tried to make the best of it.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Luis Hernandez: It's been a bit of a journey, but I'm grateful for the support my parents gave us. They worked in different places and businesses, but the common thread was their dedication to providing for us. My dad would often do construction work during the warmer months, but in the colder months, he'd find temporary jobs at local stores. My mom worked in a grocery store, which was usually during the evenings or on weekends. Their most important activities were ensuring we had a roof over our head and food on the table, no matter how tough it got. It's a reminder of how much they sacrificed for us, and I strive to honor their example by working hard and taking care of our family.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Luis Hernandez: Looking ahead, I hope that Luis Jr. continues to grow and thrive. I dream of being able to provide him with more opportunities and a better future. I also hope that we can finally pay off our mortgage and build up our savings. It would be a relief to have some financial stability, and I think it would make a big difference for us. On a personal level, I hope to continue growing as a person and to strengthen our family bonds. We've faced a lot of challenges together, and I believe that our resilience and love for each other will carry us through whatever comes next.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Luis Hernandez: The thing I value the most in my life is undoubtedly my family. They are the foundation of everything I do, and knowing that I can provide for them and see Luis Jr. grow brings me immense joy and purpose. It's not just about the material things; it's about the love and support we share every day. Even though we face challenges, the bond we have is unbreakable, and that's what truly matters.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, it's clear that managing stress and finding coping strategies have been at the forefront of my experiences. The past year has brought a lot of challenges, especially with balancing homeschooling Luis Jr. and managing household responsibilities. I've found that taking breaks, doing yoga, and talking things over with friends in the support group have been helpful. It's important to me to maintain a routine, even if it's flexible, as it provides a sense of normalcy. Despite the tight budget and fluctuating expenses, we've been able to save a little each month, which helps with unexpected expenses. Owning our home is a significant responsibility, but it also gives us a sense of stability. The love and support from my family, particularly Maria, Luis Jr., and our extended family, have been instrumental in navigating these uncertainties. The support group I joined has been a lifeline, providing emotional support and practical advice. Prioritizing mental health and finding healthy coping mechanisms is crucial, and I'm grateful for the community around me that helps us through tough times.

Completing this interview and sharing my life story has been both humbling and enlightening. It's amazing to reflect on how much my family, community, and personal experiences have shaped who I am today. From the challenges of growing up in a modest household to the turning point of receiving a scholarship that changed the course of my life, every step has been a lesson in perseverance and gratitude. The support of my wife Maria, the love of my son Luis Jr., and the unwavering encouragement from my parents have been the pillars of my strength. The community around us, from the local church to the support group, has provided a safety net during tough times. While the path has been filled with ups and downs, the knowledge that I can make a difference in the lives of those around me, even in small ways, gives me a sense of purpose. This interview has reminded me of the importance of staying true to my values, supporting my family, and continuing to grow both personally and professionally. It's a journey that I'm committed to, and I'm grateful for every step of the way.
